metadata.title: Technological change and wage premiums amongst high-skilled labour

relevance.topic: Technological change and wage premiums amongst high-skilled labour
relevance.relevance: The study examines the impact of the steam engine on wages of high-skilled seamen, providing insights into labor displacement and wage changes due to technological change.

design.sample_characteristics: The sample consists of Swedish sailors from the Seamen's House documents, covering 9592 different individuals.

dependent_variables.wage_changes: High-skilled seamen on steam-powered vessels received a wage premium compared to those on sailing vessels.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Period of economic growth and transition from sailing ships to steam-powered vessels.
historical_context.institutional_context: The Seamen's House in Sweden collected data on sailors for military use.

outcomes.main_findings: High-skilled seamen on steam-powered vessels received a wage premium compared to those on sailing vessels, with the premium declining over time.
outcomes.conclusions: The study concludes that technological change led to wage premiums for high-skilled labor, with evidence of wage polarization being subtle.

quality_assessment.methodological_limitations: The precision and robustness of the analysis may suffer from sample size and an arbitrary cutoff point.
quality_assessment.coherence: The data consistently show wage premiums for high-skilled labor on steam-powered vessels.
quality_assessment.adequacy_of_data: The study uses a large dataset of 16,091 observations, providing substantial evidence for the conclusions.
quality_assessment.relevance: The study is relevant to understanding the impact of technological change on labor markets, particularly in historical contexts.
